body:
### Describe your issue

This is to collect and discuss remaining work for the Cython 3.1 release.

[Planned features](https://github.com/cython/cython/milestone/65) for this milestone are:

*    Remove code for Python 2 and Python < 3.8.
*    Integrate better with Python 3.
*    Improve support for the Limited API.
*    Start supporting GIL-free Python 3.13.
*    Support the Py3.13 `sys.monitoring` API.
*    Support and use `am_send` for coroutines.

All done. The non-measurable goals in this list do not block a release.

Please link issues and PRs in comments below that you want to see considered or discussed for inclusion.

comment_data.body:
I'm in favour of 3.1 sooner rather than later.

Ideally there's one more limited API bit I'd like to get in:
https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6479/files (or possibly https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/5871, but I'd live with the first one).

There's a couple of sys.monitoring bugs that might be worth a look (https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/6503 https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/6399) but I don't really think they should block it.

From my side if we can include:
* #5499 - it should be almost done or done
* #6091 - there are no open point maybe it is ready to go
* #6406 - this needs to be reviewed by @scoder. Maybe not ready to go. If it delays release, we should move it.
Yes and this one - most likely you already know about it: #5479 since user waits for it but I am not sure if it is ready to go ...

> Yes and this one - most likely you already know about it: #5479 since user waits for it but I am not sure if it is ready to go ...

I'm quickly trying another approach...

> I'm quickly trying another approach...

which I've convinced myself doesn't easily work...
I have created a new PR for const global variables: #6542. I hope it is ready to go to 3.1...
https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/6449 would probably be a good candidate?
Perhaps also #6513, so users can start playing around with subinterpreters a bit?

> Perhaps also #6513, so users can start playing around with subinterpreters a bit?

My view is:
* if it's simple to review then it's be good to merge it so users can start telling us the many ways that subinterpreters are broken in Cython.
* if @scoder looks at it and immediately thinks "hmmmm.... this is dubious" then we shouldn't wait around to get it in shape.
Any planned release date for `3.1.0` ? Thanks!

I'm eagerly awaiting the release of 3.1.0. PyPy 3.11 (v7.3.18) was just released and lxml fails to compile using Cython 3.0.11 with this version of PyPy. 3.1.0a1 has #6482 which fixes the compile error.

> 3.1.0a1 has [#6482](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6482) which fixes the compile error.

I'll release 3.0.12 with that fix tomorrow.

3.0.12 is released.

I'd like to follow up with a new 3.1 alpha in a few days. Time to nominate PRs for inclusion.
https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/5871 is known to unlock ABI3 builds for some packages built against numpy, so I'd really like it to be included in Cython 3.1

> I'd like to follow up with a new 3.1 alpha in a few days.

Given a the release cadence here, and that it's been 2 months since comments like
> @scoder: Planned features for this milestone are: [...] All done.

> @da-woods: I'm in favour of 3.1 sooner rather than later.

... would it be worth considering to go for `3.1.0b1` as the next release, rather than alpha2? That'd still leave plenty of opportunity for bugfixes etc. before GA.
I put #6531 to Cython 3.1 to this release with hope it can make it but do not postpone the release...

With gh-6728 now merged (awesome, thanks so much everyone involved!) I hope you don't mind if I ask about current expectations for 3.1.0 here. Was gh-6728 the last feature that needed to go in? There are 16 open issues in https://github.com/cython/cython/milestone/65 still, quite a few of which are minor or carried over from older releases. I know timelines are hard, but a rough idea would be really helpful. Or any issues that are actual blockers and may be feasible to tackle for someone with some time to spare but not very in-depth Cython internals knowledge.

I'll see if I can get 3.1.0b1 released today. If that succeeds, I'd let it rest over the next three weeks, including the release of CPython 3.14a7 which should have a few C level fixes for us, and then see where we stand regarding the final release based on user feedback.

That's great to hear, thanks @scoder. 3.1.0b1 will also be helpful for adopting the shared component, since we can then package 3.1.0b1 in conda-forge which then unblocks merging use of the shared component in SciPy immediately.
3.1.0b1 is out in the wild. Have fun with it. :)

I've started preparing a release candidate, currently looking through any last minute PRs that can be merged.

So far I came across https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6382 which I think I'd like to include to improve the namespace behaviour of cpdef enums.

Anything else worth nominating from your side?
I'd quite like to get https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6579 in if possible. Nothing else significant from me.

I got to look into https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/5750 again and started writing up https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6808 to fix it. It turned into something that seems both a very nice behaviour to have and no longer suitable for a release candidate.

Basically, it widens the meaning of the Python types `int` and `float` (and potentially `complex`) to accept compatible types, so that you can write
```python
def func(arg: float | None):
    assert arg is None or type(arg) is float  # definitely an object

func(5)  # passes the Python float object 5.0, instead of raising a TypeError as it did before
```
And similarly, it accepts subtypes of numeric builtin number types and internally converts them to their builtin base type. Previously, subtypes of builtin types were rejected if you typed the function argument as `x: int`, for example.

I'm aware that this is not what Python does. It's a tradeoff between static typing that employs exact builtin type declarations for speed improvements (but annoyingly rejects everything else) and Python typing semantics that happily accepts 'int' for 'float' typed arguments and variables (and that even generally allows any type at runtime), and that does not care whether it receives a builtin type or subtype, obeying the subtype's behaviour.

For Cython, builtin type or subtype makes the difference between "I know how the type behaves and can optimise it" and "any behaviour might be overridden and I cannot make any assumptions". Converting to the base type helps in two ways: it no longer rejects subtypes, but still allows static assumptions about the (converted) object at hand.

This is a risky change at this late point. I would normally vote for postponing it. But to me, the relaxation in type acceptance seems very tempting, and solves real world problems.

I'd be happy to get some feedback and testing for the PR.

> This is a risky change at this late point. I would normally vote for postponing it. But to me, the relaxation in type acceptance seems very tempting, and solves real world problems.

Please please consider putting it into 3.2 . #5750 seems of _very_ low importance to be honest, compared to getting out a release with free-threading support that we've been very keen to see since about August last year, and the lack of which is causing a lot of issues and extra work. Plus a lot of other nice features like better Limited API support and support for shared components - getting any one of those features into the hands of users sooner is by itself already a lot more impactful than a change to #5750 one release earlier.

Example of delay impact for shared components: we have SciPy 1.16.0rc1 scheduled for May 21st (final release in June), and I'd really like to be able to use the shared component feature - the [benefit](https://github.com/scipy/scipy/issues/22775#issuecomment-2772174824) of that is large enough that we implemented support for it in SciPy within days of it being merged in Cython `master`. Holding off on a Cython release candidate now to merge a late risky change sounds like it'll cause Cython 3.1.0 to not be available in time for SciPy 1.16.

On #5750 itself: it has only one incoming link from the Ray project which then worked around it, so not really a burning issue. And there is no ideal solution to that issue anyway since Python static typing semantics are different, as you say there.

Thanks for your comment. I'll leave the PR where it is and make sure Cython 3.1 is out in time. Without this change, we're probably set for a RC.

Note, though, that https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6808 isn't just about fixing https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/5750. That issue was more of a trigger to get working on it. The PR improves on several long standing annoyances in the language that let users run into differences between builtin types and extension types, prevent typed Python code from being accepted by Cython, make compiled code behave differently from the original Python code, etc. We cannot resolve these issues completely, but I consider it a visible step towards more user friendly typing.

But I can live with it missing 3.1. It will definitely benefit from a longer testing period.
Thanks so much @scoder!

labels.description: Release planning and general project goal discussions
labels.name: Planning

milestone.description:
* Remove code for Python 2 and Python < 3.8.
* Integrate better with Python 3.
* Improve support for the Limited API.
* Start supporting GIL-free Python 3.13.
* Support the Py3.13 `sys.monitoring` API.
* Support and use `am_send` for coroutines.

title: Prepare release of Cython 3.1
